Graphical abstract Novel heterostructured TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 composites were synthesized by a combination of solid-state and sol–gel methods, and were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, and photocurrent measurements. The results of photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue over the as-prepared materials indicate that photocatalytic efficiency is closely related to the composition of the materials, and the 30%TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 catalyst exhibits the best adsorption and photodegradation efficiency under sunlight or visible-light irradiation. The adsorption capacity of 30%TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 for methylene blue is 18.59mg/g calculated based on the Langmuir adsorption model. Adsorption kinetics studies show that the process fits well with a pseudo-second-order rate mechanism. Recycle experiments confirm that the 30%TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 catalyst is stable. The present work illustrates a new way for the design and syntheses of stable and high-efficiency catalysts applicable for the degradation of organic pollutants. Keywords Adsorption–degradation Heterostructured Photocatalysis Synthetic methods Solid solution 1 Introduction Photocatalysis is an effective method for the harness of solar energy. The use of a TiO2 photochemical electrode for water splitting was first reported by Fujishima and Honda in 1972 [1]. However, the wide bandgap of anatase TiO2 (3.2eV) restricts its photocatalytic applications in the visible-light region. In addition, it is generally observed that due to electron-hole recombination, the quantum yield is low and catalytic efficiency is poor. Efforts were put in to modify anatase TiO2 for better performance through the doping of TiO2 with nonmetals such as N [2–5], S [6], C [7], F [8], I [9] and B [10] or by converting TiO2 into a heterostructured catalyst [11–13]. Transition metal sulfides, in particular CoS, CoSe and ZnS, as important chalcogenide semiconductors, have been extensively studied and applied as supercapacitor, infrared lasers in fiber optics, battery, and photocatalyst due to their unique physical and chemical properties [14–16]. And CoS1−x Se x is a solid solution semiconductor with good photocatalytic activity and adjustable band structures through controlling its composition [17]. As well known, compared to single-component photocatalysts, the heterostructured counterparts exhibit superior photocatalytic activity because their band gaps can be regulated through the control of composition for efficient separation of photogenerated charges. In recent years, much attention has been given to the design and synthesis of heterostructured catalysts. However, it is uncommon to come across those that are based on solid solutions because it is not easy to prepare this kind of catalysts by conventional methods. In the literature, the methods adopted for the preparation of heterostructured photocatalysts are mainly hydrothermal (solvothermal) [18,19], coprecipitation [20], sol–gel [21] or a combination of them. In addition, it is known that solid-state synthesis is a traditional and facile approach to prepare semiconductors with uniform and adjustable composition. Especially, this method is good approach to the generation of solid-solution semiconductors with good crystallinity and high purity [22,23]. It is hence envisaged that solid-solution photocatalysts can be better synthesized through solid-state reactions. During photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants, there are adsorption and photodegradation steps. It was reported that photocatalysts, especially the heterostructured ones, are poor in adsorption activity [24–29]. It is hence desirable to prepare heterostructured photocatalysts that are synergetically effective in both adsorption and photodegradation. In view of Co4S4.23Se3.77 with good photocatalytic performance and matching band potentials to those of TiO2, we prepared heterostructured TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 through a combination of solid-state and sol–gel methods because the Co4S4.23Se3.77 solid solution can be well prepared by solid state method and then TiO2 nanoparticales can load on the surface of Co4S4.23Se3.77. This is the first report of such kind. For the elucidation of the related adsorption and photocatalytic mechanism, we investigated the synergetic adsorption–degradation effects on the decomposition of methylene blue (MB) under sunlight and visible-light irradiation over the as-prepared catalysts. The present work provides a new strategy for the design and synthesis of heterostructured catalysts for effective degradation of organic pollutants. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials In this study, cobalt (Co, ≥99.99%), selenium (Se, ≥99.99%), and sublimed sulfur (S≥99.95%) were purchased from Aladdin Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China), whereas tetrabutyl titanate (C16H36O4Ti, CP) was supplied by Shanghai KEFENG Chemical Reagent Co., Lnc. (Shanghai, China). Nitric acid (HNO3, AR) and ethanol (C2H5OH, AR) were obtained from Guangzhou Xilong Chemical Co., Ltd. (Guangzhou, China). Water was purified using a Milli-Q water system (Bedford, USA). Other chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Syntheses 2.2.1 Synthesis of pure Co4S4.23Se3.77 The Co4S4.23Se3.77 (CSS) solid solution was prepared by solid-state reaction of a mixture of Co (4mmol, 235.7mg), S (4mmol, 128mg) and Se (4mmol, 316mg) at 850°C. The starting materials were ground to fine powders and pressed into a pellet. The pellet was loaded into a Pyrex tube which then was evacuated to 1×10−2 Pa and flame-sealed. The tube was placed into a computer-controlled furnace, heated from the room temperature (RT) to 850°C at a rate of 25°C/h, kept at 850°C for 72h, and slowly cooled down to 50°C at a rate of 2°C/h. Then it was finally cooled down to RT over a period of 1h and a crop of black CCS crystals that was stable in air was collected. Semiquantitative microscope element analysis on several grains of the as-obtained single crystals over a field-emission scanning electron microscope equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscope confirmed that Co, S and Se were present in an approximate molar ratio of 4.0:4.15:3.85 (see Table S1 in Supplementary information), and there was no detection of any other elements. Based on the preliminary results and followed similar procedures, we obtained a light-red crystalline CCS sample with the exact composition through reaction of a mixture of Co/S/Se in a molar ratio of 4/4.23/3.77 at 850°C for 72h. The purity of the as-prepared crystalline sample was confirmed by XRD powder diffraction. 2.2.2 Syntheses of heterostructured TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 composite The heterostructured TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 composite was prepared by a sol–gel method. The typical procedure for the preparation of TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 with a designated TiO2 to Co4S4.23Se3.77 weight ratio is as followed: With stirring tetrabutyl titanate (0.75mL, CP) was dissolved in a mixture of ethanol (2.0mL) and glacial acetic (0.075mL) at 80°C. Then a mixed solution of HNO3 (0.15mL, AR), distilled water (0.1mL) and ethanol (1mL) was added slowly into it under stirring. At this stage, a calculated amount of Co4S4.23Se3.77 (0.1667–0.8335g) prepared by the solid-state method was added into the as-obtained solution. For example, heterostructured 30%TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 (weight ratio of TiO2 to Co4S4.23Se3.77 =3:10) was prepared by using 0.5g Co4S4.23Se3.77 and 0.75mL tetrabutyl titanate. Finally, the obtained sample was vacuum dried at 120°C for 5h and then calcined at 400°C for 2h. Hereinafter, the Co4S4.23Se3.77 loaded with 10%, 20%, 30%, 40% and 50% TiO2 are denoted as 1TCSS, 2TCSS, 3TCSS, 4TCSS and 5TCSS, respectively. 2.3 Characterization The crystal phases of powder samples were identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 ADVANCE, Germany) using graphite monochromatized Cu-Kα (λ =1.5406Å) radiation. The XRD data for indexing and cell-parameter calculations were collected in a scan mode with scanning speed of 2°/min in the 2θ range between 20° and 70°. The morphology of samples was observed with a scanning electron microscope (SEM, FEI SIRION, Holand) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM-200CX, Japan). Composition analyses on several randomly selected samples of the as-prepared catalysts were performed on a field-emission scanning electron microscope equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscope (EDS). The Co/Ti molar ratio of the as-prepared samples was also determined based on data collected over an inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES; Vista-MPX, VARIAN). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250, ThermoFisher SCIENTIFIC, China) measurements were taken with a VG Escalab 250 spectrometer equipped with an Al anode (Al-Kα=1486.7eV). UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were measured with a PE Lambda 900 UV/Vis spectrophotometer at room temperature. The finely ground sample powder was coated on a BaSO4 plate which was also used as a reference. The absorbance spectra were converted by the Kubelka–Munk method. Raman measurements were performed using a JY LabRam HR800 spectrometer equipped with a microscope, and laser radiation of λ =514.5nm (at 5mV) was used as excitation source. Photoluminescence analyses were performed on a fluorescence spectrometer (F-7000, Hitachi, Japan). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of samples were measured by means of N2 adsorption over a NOVA 2000e (Quantachrome) equipment. X-ray diffraction patterns of Co4S4.23Se3.77 single crystal (black in color) were collected at 293K over a SMART APEX CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The intensity data were all collected with ω scan technique and corrected for LP factors as well as for absorption by the multiscan method. The structure of CSS was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 with full-matrix least-squares techniques using Siemens SHELXTL™ version 5.1 package of crystallographic software [30]. We conducted final refinements on anisotropic displacement parameters (for all atoms) with secondary extinction correction. The crystallographic data of CSS are listed in Table S2. Further details of the crystal structures can be obtained from the Fachinformationszentrum Karlsruhe, 76344 Eggenstein-Leopoldshafen, Germany, on quoting the depository number ICSD-424304. Electrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI 660D electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua, China) using a standard three-electrode cell having a working electrode, a platinum wire as counter electrode, and a standard calomel electrode in saturated KCl as reference electrode. The working electrodes were prepared by dip-coating: 10mg of photocatalyst was suspended in 100μL acetone, and the as-produced slurry was then dip-coated onto a 2.5cm×1cm fluorine-tin oxide (FTO) glass electrode. After drying under ambient condition and with the electrolyte (0.5M Na2SO4) purged with nitrogen, the cell was ready for photocurrent measurements using a 300W xenon lamp as the source of simulated sunlight. 2.4 Adsorption and photodegradation evaluation Adsorption activity of the as-prepared sample of 3TCSS was evaluated for the degradation of MB in the dark. Similarly, photocatalytic activities of the as-prepared samples were evaluated for the degradation of MB under irradiation of visible light and sunlight. A 300W Xe lamp (PerfectLight, wavelength range: 320nm≤ λ ≤780nm, light intensity: 160mW/cm2) was used as source of visible light (cutoff filter applied, λ >420nm) and simulated sunlight. First, 50mg of photocatalyst was added to 50mL of 10mg/L MB, and the suspension was kept in the dark under stirring for 0.5h to ensure adsorption/desorption equilibrium. Then the system was subject to irradiation, and 3mL aliquots were collected at designated intervals. After immediate centrifugation, the concentration of MB in the liquid phase was determined by UV–vis spectrophotometry (Cary 300 spectrophotometer). The extent of mineralization of MB was followed by using a total organic carbon analyzer (TOC; Shimadzu TOC-L CSH CN200). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials characterization As shown in Figs. S1 and S2, the structure of the Co4S4.23Se3.77 (CSS) solid solution is composed of distorted Se2Co6/S2Co6 octahedra that contain six-coordinated Co atoms and tetrahedrally coordinated S/Se atoms. The two S/Se atom pairs form S2/Se2 dumb-bells having an oxidation state of −2, and each Co atom shows an oxidation state of +2. The structure of CSS is similar to that of CoSSe compound reported by Nahigian et al. [31]. The Se2Co6/S2Co6 octahedra are linked together through the sharing of corners or edges to form a 3-D framework. A better insight into the 3D CSS network can be achieved by topological approach (Fig. S3). When the S2/Se2 dumb-bells are reduced to six-connected nodes and Co(1) atoms are treated as six-connected nodes, the architecture of CSS can be seen as a 3D 6-connected PCU topology with Schläfli symbol of (412.63). Fig. 1 shows XRD patterns of the as-prepared catalysts. With the increase of TiO2 loading, the characteristic signals of TiO2 intensify but there are no significant shifts of the principal CSS peaks. The results indicate that TiO2 exists as a separate phase and there is no incorporation of TiO2 into the CSS lattice, in consistent with the results of ICP measurement (Table S3). The morphology of the TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 composites was investigated by SEM. As shown in Fig. S4, the particle sizes of the samples are in the range of 1–10μm, and 3TCSS is the smallest in size. With increase of TiO2 loading, there is increase in the number of TiO2 particles; the particle sizes of TiO2 become larger when TiO2 loading is higher than 30%. It is observed that there is uniform distribution of TiO2 particles on the 3TCSS surface. As shown in Fig. S5a and b, TEM and HRTEM images of 3TCSS clearly show the interface of TiO2 and CSS. The fringes of d =0.327nm and d =0.515nm are in agreement with the (110) plane of TiO2 and a plane of CSS, respectively. This result confirms that there exist heterojunctions between TiO2 and CSS in the composites. The EDS result further confirms TiO2 particles deposited on the surface of CSS (Fig. S6). The full scan and high-resolution Ti-2p, Co-2p, S-2p, Se-3d, and O-1s spectra of 3TCSS collected in XPS studies are showed in Fig. S7. One can see that there are C, O, Ti, S, Se and Co elements on the surface of 3TCSS. The carbon can be ascribed to adventitious hydrocarbon (Fig. S7a). The peaks with binding energies around 781.1 and 796.1eV can be ascribed to Co-2p3/2 and Co-2p1/2 signals (Fig. S7b), which are comparable to those of Co2+ [32]. The high-resolution spectrum of Ti-2p region is shown in Fig. S7c. The peaks centered at 458.75 and 464.65eV can be assigned to Ti-2p3/2 and Ti-2p1/2 signals, respectively, in consistent with those of TiO2 reported by Cao et al. [33]. As shown in Fig. S7d and e, the peak at 165.35eV can be assigned to S-2p, and those around 57.75 and 57.85eV to Se-3d5/2 and Se-3d3/2, respectively. Because there are no XPS reports on Se1− and S1− in the literature, it is not possible for us to make any comparison. Nonetheless, based on the EDS, XPS and XRD results, it is reasonable for us to deduce that there are CSS species (Se and S are both −1 in oxidation state) in 3TCSS. The O-1s band is shown in Fig. S7f. The peak at 530.65eV can be assigned to Ti-O of TiO2 [34], whereas the peak at 532.5eV to adsorbed oxygen species and/or subsurface low-coordinated oxygen ions O− [35]. The O-1s peak at 532.5eV can also be ascribed to surface hydroxyl OH and/or carbonate species [36]. Overall, the results demonstrate that there are TiO2 species in 3TCSS. 3.2 Photodegradation of MB over the as-prepared catalysts The photocatalytic activities of the as-prepared catalysts were evaluated in the photodecomposition of MB under the irradiation of simulated sunlight and visible light (λ >420nm). Before the start of irradiation, the reaction mixture was continuously stirred in the dark for 0.5h for the establishment of adsorption/desorption equilibrium. A decrease of light absorption at a wavelength of 664nm detected over an aqueous solution of MB under visible-light irradiation would imply decrease of MB content. Fig. 2a shows the plots of MB decrease as a function of stirring time in the dark and irradiation time under visible light as detected over CSS, 1TCSS, 2TCSS, 4TCSS, and 5TCSS. One can see that when 3TCSS is used, there is 78% decrease of MB concentration after continuous stirring in the dark for 30min, whereas in the cases of the others, the decrease of MB concentration is not as significant. Under the irradiation of visible light, the catalysts with TiO2 loaded on CSS perform better than that without (i.e. CCS), especially so for the one with 30wt% TiO2 loading (i.e. 3TCSS). In fact, the best photocatalytic activity is observed over 3TCSS. With TiO2 loading exceeding 30wt%, there is decline of photocatalytic activity. The removal of MB is 100% after 40min in the presence of 3TCSS (see also Fig. S8), while MB degradation is approximately 62%, 78%, 72%, 69%, and 67% in the presence of CSS, 1TCSS, 2TCSS, 4TCSS and 5TCSS after 120min, respectively. The results demonstrate that the loading of an appropriate amount of TiO2 on CSS is crucial for high performance. Meanwhile, the efficiency of MB adsorption on 3TCSS in the dark was investigated in greater detail. Apparently, MB is removed from the liquid phase in the dark by means of adsorption on 3TCSS, and MB removal is about 78% at 30min. Afterward, there is nearly no removal of MB from the liquid phase, implying that the system has reached adsorption/desorption equilibrium in the first 30min. As shown in Fig. S8, MB can be completely removed under visible light irradiation within 40min. The results suggest that after the establishment of adsorption/desorption equilibrium in the dark, the removal of MB is by means of photocatalytic degradation. Noteworthily, the removal rate of MB over a sample of physically mixed TiO2 (P25) and CSS is obviously lower than that of 3TCCS in the dark (Fig. S9). And there is a sharp increase of MB concentration in the liquid phase within the first 20min of irradiation, plausibly due to MB desorption (Fig. S9). Since such phenomena are different from those observed over 3TCSS, it is considered that the better performance of 3TCSS is due to synergetic effects of adsorption and photodegradation as induced by the heterojunctions created in 3TCSS. In the case of photodegradation of MB under irradiation of simulated sunlight, the trend of photocatalytic activity with rise of TiO2 loading is similar to that detected under visible-light irradiation (Fig. 2a and b). Again, highest removal rate is observed over 3TCSS which is 100% within 40min. Over CSS, 1TCSS, 2TCSS, 4TCSS, and 5TCSS, the degradation of MB is around 64%, 83%, 82%, 79% and 78% after 120min, respectively. In view of the possibility of generating intermediate species that are more toxic or carcinogenic than the parent organic compounds in a degradation process [37], we monitored the extent of MB mineralization after the degradation process. Fig. S10 (Supplementary information) displays that the decomposition of MB over 3TCSS is ca. 95% and 93% in 40min under the irradiation of simulated sunlight and visible light, respectively. With such efficiency, 3TCSS can be considered as a good candidate for MB photodegradation. To the best of our knowledge, the adsorption ability and photocatalytic activity of 3TCSS is the highest among the catalysts reported in the literature for MB removal [24,38–44]. Table S4 (Supplementary information) shows that the BET surface area of 3TCSS is ca. 49.825m2/g, whereas those of TiO2 (synthesized in our group), CSS, 1TCSS, 2TCSS, 4TCSS, and 5TCSS are ca. 5.095, 1.375, 5.872, 4.357, 3.893, and 4.298m2/g, respectively. Compared to CSS, 3TCCS is much higher in specific surface area. It is generally agreed that a catalyst with higher surface area is higher in terms of availability of active sites. Thus besides charge separation efficiency, being large in surface area is another reason for the high photocatalytic performance of 3TCSS. The BET data are reproducible and the large BET value of 3TCSS is attributed to its unique morphology (Fig. S4). 3.3 Recycling studies The lifetime of a photocatalyst is an important parameter in terms of cost saving. We tested the reusability of the 3TCCS for the photodegradation of MB under visible-light irradiation. In the test of four runs, catalyst was separated from solution by filtration, washed several times with deionized water, dried at 60°C for 2h and then used for the next run. As shown in Fig. 3 , MB removal efficiency was still higher than 82% in the fourth run. The decline of catalytic efficiency is plausibly due a decline of adsorption performance. 3.4 Adsorption performance In view of the excellent adsorption ability of 3TCSS for MB, we investigated the adsorption properties of 3TCSS. The zeta (ζ) potential of 3TCSS was measured with a zeta potential analyzer (Zetasizer Nano ZS90). Before analysis, 2mg 3TCSS was dispersed in 10mL water and subject to ultrasonic treatment for 30min for homogeneous suspension. The zeta potential of 3TCSS was −10.8eV in water. Based on the fact that 3TCSS is negatively charged, it is deduced that MB adsorption on 3TCSS is a kind of electrostatic adsorption. 3.5 Adsorption kinetics Fig. 4 shows the time dependence of the adsorbed amounts of MB on 3TCSS and P25. One can see that there is rapid adsorption of MB on 3TCSS in the first 10min. When it is close to adsorption/desorption equilibrium, the rate of adsorption slows down. In addition, the 3TCSS has stronger affinity for MB than P25. We used the pseudo-first-order and pseudo-second-order kinetic model [45] to study the adsorption mechanism, respectively. The pseudo-first-order equation is given as follows: lg ( q e − q t ) = lg ( q e ) − K 1 t 2.303 where K 1 (min−1) is the adsorption rate constant of pseudo-first-order model, q e and q t (mg/g) are the amount on adsorbent at equilibrium and time t, respectively. The pseudo-second-order equation is given as follows: t q t = t q e + 1 K 2 q e 2 h 0 = K 2 ⋅ q e 2 where K 2 (gmg−1 min−1) is the rate constant for the pseudo-second-order adsorption; q e is the amount of solute adsorbed at equilibrium (mgg−1); q t is the amount of solute adsorbed on the sorbent at time t (mgg−1) and h 0 is the initial adsorption rate (mgg−1 min−1). The plot of lg(q e − q t ) versus t would result in a linear plot, and one can obtain q e and K 1 from the slope and intercept, respectively (Fig. 5a). In addition, the plot of t/q t versus t would result in a linear plot, and one can obtain q e, h 0 and K 2 from the slope and intercept, respectively (Fig. 5b). The adsorption kinetic constants and regression coefficients are summarized in Table 1 . The R 2 2 values are is close to 1 but that of R 1 2 deviates from 1, indicating that the adsorption of MB on 3TCSS follows the pseudo-second-order model but not the pseudo-first-order model. In other words, the adsorption of MB on 3TCSS is mainly a process of MB interaction with the binding sites of 3TCSS. The theoretical adsorption capacity obtained from the pseudo-second order model is 5.63mgg−1. 3.6 Adsorption isotherm We adopted the Langmuir model and the Freundlich model to study the distribution of MB in the liquid and adsorbent phases. The linearized Langmuir and Freundlich isotherms are described by the following equations: Langmuir model: C e q e = C e q max + 1 K L q max Freundlich model: lg ⁡ q e = 1 n lg ⁡ C e + lg ⁡ K F where C e (mgL−1) is the equilibrium concentration, q e (mgg−1) is the amount of MB adsorbed at equilibrium, q max (mgg−1) is the theoretical maximum monolayer capacity, K L (Lg−1) is the Langmuir constant, and K F (mg1−1/n L−1/n g−1) is the Freundlich constant The binding property of 3TCSS for MB adsorption was investigated through static adsorption tests. Linearized form of Langmuir and Freundlich adsorption isotherm model were applied to fit the equilibrium data (Fig. 6 a and b and Table 2 ). It can be seen that the Langmuir model matches pretty well with the equilibrium data, indicating that the adsorption of MB on 3TCSS is homogenous. 3.7 Photodegradation mechanism It is known that photoinduced holes, hydroxyl (•OH) and super oxygen (•O2−) radicals are extremely active and they trigger the oxidation of organic pollutants in a photodegration process [46]. To investigate the related mechanism, it is important to identify the major oxidant [47,48]. In the present work, we conducted trapping investigations using sodium oxalate as hole scavenger, isopropyl alcohol as •OH scavenger and benzoquinone [42,43] as •O2− scavenger. In addition, experiment with N2 bubbling into the MB solution (to eliminate dissolved oxygen) as well as that with O2 bubbling into the MB solution (to increase dissolved oxygen) during photocatalytic degradation were conducted. For these studies, adsorption/desorption equilibrium was established (continuous stirring for 0.5h in the dark) before the start of degradation reaction. In the system containing 3TCSS, electron–hole pairs are produced under visible-light irradiation, yielding radicals and holes as oxidants. With the addition of benzoquinone and isopropyl alcohol, the photodegradation of MB is ca. 23% and 26%, respectively, in 40min. Compared to the case of no addition of scavengers (100% degradation in 40min), there was distinct decline of photodegradation activity when isopropyl alcohol and benzoquinone are added (Fig. 7 ). It is noted that the photodegradation of MB is nearly unaffected by the addition of sodium oxalate (removal rate is 94% in 40min). It can be concluded that both •O2− and •OH are the active species responsible for the photodegradation of MB. Furthermore, the use of N2 to purge the solution results in marked decrease of MB degradation (removal rate is 27% in 40min). On the other hand, when O2 is bubbled into the MB solution, there is clear improvement of MB degradation (Fig. 7). The phenomena reveal that the trapping of photoelectrons with molecular oxygen is crucial. The major steps for the generation of •OH are: (1) O2 +e− → •O2 − (2) •O2 − +2H+ +e− →H2O2 (3) H2O2 +e− → •OH+OH− (4) H2O2 +O2 → •OH+H+ +O2 − In these processes, photoelectrons are captured by O2 to yield •O2 − and H2O2 (Eqs. (1) and (2)). The interaction of H2O2 with photoelectrons or O2 results in the generation of hydroxyl radicals (Eqs. (3) and (4)) [46,49]. Therefore, O2 prevents the recombination of photogenerated electron–hole pairs as well as participates in the production of •OH. This well explains why the bubbling of O2 into the solution can markedly improve the photodegradation of MB. 3.8 Photocatalytic enhancement mechanism Photocurrent measurements were conducted over FTO electrodes with CSS, 1TCSS, 2TCSS, 3TCSS, 4TCSS, and 5TCSS deposition under the irradiation of simulated sunlight (Fig. S11). There is fast and uniform photocurrent response in each switch-on and switch-off event. The photocurrent transients at the two electrodes are different in shape, and the photo-responses are reversible. It is observed that the photocurrent of the 3TCSS electrode is the biggest and about 14 times that of the CSS electrode. The results indicate that separation efficiency of photo-induced electrons and holes is improved as a result of electronic interaction between TiO2 and CSS. The photocurrent response of CSS is weak, in consistent with its photocatalytic activity. The excellent photocatalytic activity of 3TCSS can hence be related to its high photocurrent response. We studied the electrochemical properties of the photocatalysts using a standard three-electrode cell. Fig. S12 shows the Mott-Sckottky (MS) plots with Co4S4.23Se3.77 and TiO2 being working electrodes (0.5M K2SO4 as electrolyte). We observe reversed sigmoidal plots with an overall shape typical of n-type semiconductors. The V fb as calculated from the x intercepts of the linear region are found to be −0.58 and −0.1eV vs SCE (equivalent to −0.34 and 0.14eV vs. NHE, respectively) for Co4S4.23Se3.77 and TiO2, respectively. The V fb value of TiO2 is similar to that reported previously by us [50]. It is generally accepted that the bottom of the conduction band (CB) in most n-type semiconductors is more negative (by ∼0.2eV) than the flat band potential [50,51]. Putting that into consideration, the potentials of the CB of Co4S4.23Se3.77 and TiO2 are −0.54 and −0.06eV, respectively. The band positions can be calculated by the following empirical formulas: E CB = E VB − E g, and the valence band (VB) of Co4S4.23Se3.77 and TiO2 are 1.89 and 3.14eV, respectively (E g values of Co4S4.23Se3.77 and TiO2 can be obtained from Fig. S13). Based on the above experimental results and discussion, we propose the most plausible mechanism for the degradation of pollutants under sunlight irradiation (Fig. 8 ). Under sunlight irradiation, electrons (e−) in the VB are excited to CB, with the same amount of holes (h+) left in the VB of TiO2 and CSS. Then, electrons in the CB of CSS flow into the CB of TiO2 because the CB of CSS is more negative than that of TiO2. In the mean time, the photogenerated holes in the VB of TiO2 flow into the VB of CSS because the VB of CSS is more negative than that of TiO2. The net result is a restriction in the recombination photoelectrons and holes. Because the CB potential of TiO2 (−0.06eV) is more negative than E 0(O2/•O2 −) (−0.046eV vs NHE), the photogenerated electrons in TiO2 react with O2 to yield •O2 − for the subsequent formation of •OH radicals. As powerful oxidative species, the •OH radicals activate organic pollutants, leading to their decomposition. 4 Conclusions Heterostructured TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 composites were synthesized for the first time by a combination of solid-state and sol–gel methods. With excellent adsorption and degradation abilities, the 3TCSS catalyst is efficient for methylene blue (MB) degradation under sunlight or visible-light irradiation. The adsorption capacity of 3TCSS towards methylene blue (MB) is 18.59mg/g calculated based on the Langmuir adsorption model. Kinetics studies show that the adsorption process fits well with a pseudo-second-order rate mechanism, suggesting chemical adsorption of MB on 3TCSS. In the study of the photocatalytic mechanism, it is found that the presence of molecular oxygen is crucial for the degradation of MB. The high efficiency of 3TCSS can be ascribed to its high BET surface areas and the unique heterojunctions created at the TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 interfaces. In a test run of four cycles, the 3TCSS catalyst shows good stability and reusability. coredata.dc:description: Novel heterostructured TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 composites were synthesized by a combination of solid-state and sol–gel methods, and were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, and photocurrent measurements. The results of photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue over the as-prepared materials indicate that photocatalytic efficiency is closely related to the composition of the materials, and the 30%TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 catalyst exhibits the best adsorption and photodegradation efficiency under sunlight or visible-light irradiation. The adsorption capacity of 30%TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 for methylene blue is 18.59mg/g calculated based on the Langmuir adsorption model. Adsorption kinetics studies show that the process fits well with a pseudo-second-order rate mechanism. Recycle experiments confirm that the 30%TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 catalyst is stable. The present work illustrates a new way for the design and syntheses of stable and high-efficiency catalysts applicable for the degradation of organic pollutants.
coredata.dc:title: Adsorption–degradation synergetic effects on removal of methylene blue over heterostructured TiO2/Co4S4.23Se3.77 composites
